Every new year for the past several years, I make a resolution that I want to exercise more. My biggest problem why this never worked out was that I was not able to motivate myself and always had a thousand excuses not to. I would have times of extreme motivation and go way overboard and then have very long phases in between where I didn't feel motivated at all. For me, the problem with exercising was that I only enjoyed it when I didn't feel like I was doing it. Two years ago, I discovered Adriene's yoga videos after several friends told me that I should really have a go at them because they "aren't like other videos". I always hated going to sports classes cause I always felt embarrassed and was concerned what others might think of me and i could never find the motivation to actually go to the classes in the first place. On top of that, I always felt like it was a waste of money since I would end up not going anyway. So, having access to these classes at home where nobody could see me, right in my living room so that I wouldn't have to go anywhere, and for free, basically didn't allow for any excuses not to do them. I started off with Adriene's 30 days of yoga - and after the first few sessions I already had a moment of "hey, I can actually do this!" I finished the 30 days in just under three months but then I go injured at work and could not do yoga for a while - or so I thought. At that point, I was just using it to do a bit of exercise every day and would skip over the meditation parts. After the injury, I had a difficult time getting back into it. However, at the beginning of this year, I challenged myself to do yoga every single day - and here I am, half way through this crazy year, and I have done it! As Adriene always says, "the biggest challenge is arriving on the mat" - and it's so true! but if you look at it differently, it is really not that challenging. I told myself, even if it means just sitting on my mat and breathing for 5 min, it's ok! I don't have to exercise every time! And who doesn't have 5 min to sit down and take some time for themselves and actually "find what feels good"? And often times, when I made it onto the mat and just sat there, my motivation would actually come to me and I would end up doing a full yoga session - or even two. Since the beginning of the year, I have completed the "yoga camp", "yoga revolution", "true", "dedicate", and "home" videos. Not only have I managed to build my core muscles and get stronger and waaaay more flexible, I am also happier, feel more motivated, more focused, and have more confidence. While I always dreaded the 30th day of the yoga series because they were "freestyle" and I tried to hurry along with Adriene and constantly twisting around to stare at the screen because she wasn't talking, I have now finally found my own - "listening to my body". Funny enough, when I go freestyle and have Adriene's videos on in the background and I sometimes curiously peek at the screen, I see that she is doing the same thing as me. And sometimes I can hear her say quirky things in my head ("heyyyooo") or when I fall, I hear her go "it's ok if you fall, we'll catch ya". I just love how she doesn't show off what she is capable of doing and gives us "yogi choices" and is just a massive goof ball at times. Adriene, a HUGE thank you to you for changing my life! Thank you for being yourself and for being human (and for Benji being dog :P). You make yoga fun! These days, getting on my mat, is my favorite part of the day - and that's all thanks to you! NAMASTE <3
And by the way - I suddenly have a creaky old floor, too :D

My brain couldn't find a solution, so it bowed (quite literally, because I tucked my chin to my chest) to my body intelligence and let it do the work.
Within a year, I have come from a woman who breaks her tailbone from falling on her butt while learning to rollerblade (which was actually what got me into yoga - gentle yoga was the only exercise I could do after the accident) to one who falls down the stairs straight on her neck and ends up with just a small bruise on her upper arm.
